description.en: Corniglia is small enough to map in your head within an hour. One main street, a few branching alleys, terraces above, cliffs below. The real navigation question isn't where to go—it's how to reach the village in the first place.

body.title:
The Smallest
Map
body.subtitle: Corniglia can be walked end to end in ten minutes. The village is not a maze like its neighbors—it's a ridge, with one main street, a handful of side alleys, and terraces cascading in both directions. The navigation challenge isn't finding your way around; it's getting here.

body.quote: Corniglia's geography is straightforward: a ridge-top village with a main street running its length. Within minutes of arrival, you'll understand the layout. Within an hour, you'll know where everything is.
content: **Via Fieschi is the spine**. The main street runs along the ridge, connecting the church at one end to the terrace viewpoint at the other. Everything branches from this axis.
**The village is linear**. Unlike the maze-like layouts of other villages, Corniglia follows its ridge. You can't really get lost—walk far enough in either direction and you reach an end.
**Vertical movement is limited**. There's less climbing within Corniglia than in other villages. The steep parts are getting here; the village itself is relatively level.

**The terraces are accessible**. Paths lead from the village into the surrounding vineyards. These aren't official tourist routes—they're working agricultural paths—but they're open to respectful walkers.

items.name: The Lardarina
items.intro: 382 steps from train station to village—the gateway that defines the Corniglia experience.
items.description: The Lardarina is a brick stairway that climbs from the train station, 100 meters below, to the village. It's the first and last thing most visitors encounter. The climb takes 15-20 minutes depending on pace and fitness. The views improve with each switchback. The name supposedly comes from 'lardo'—fat—either because of the difficulty or the slippery surface when wet.
items.giuliaComment: Everyone focuses on the climb up, but I like the walk down. You've already seen the village; now you see the coast opening before you. Each switchback reveals more Mediterranean. Take it slowly on the descent.

items.name: Via Fieschi
items.intro: The ridge-top street that is Corniglia—everything else branches from this spine.
items.description: Via Fieschi runs the length of Corniglia, narrow enough that neighbors can talk across it, lined with the village's few shops, restaurants, and services. The grocery, the wine bar, the gelato—everything is here. The street opens to small piazzas at intervals, each with benches and views.
items.giuliaComment: In high season, Via Fieschi is busy by Corniglia standards. In off-season, you might walk its length without seeing another person. The street reveals the village's character—both its intimacy and its solitude.

items.name: Terrazza Santa Maria
items.intro: The terrace at the end of Via Fieschi—where the village ends and the coast reveals itself.
items.description: At the western end of Via Fieschi, a terrace opens with views toward Manarola and beyond. This is where residents and visitors gather for sunset, where benches face the sea, where the scale of Cinque Terre's coastline becomes visible. The terrace is named for the oratory that once stood here.
items.giuliaComment: This is where I come to think. The view explains everything—why people settled here, why they stayed, why they worked these impossible slopes. Everything makes sense from the terrazza.

interludes.title: The Shuttle Bus Alternative
interludes.quote: A small shuttle bus runs from the train station to the village during tourist season, bypassing the Lardarina. It runs infrequently and fills quickly, but it exists. Check schedules at the station. For luggage-laden arrivals, it's worth the wait.

body.quote: Corniglia's trails lead into terraced landscape that defines Cinque Terre—paths that farmers have walked for centuries, now available to visitors willing to explore beyond the main street.
content: **Toward Vernazza**: The coastal trail north connects to Vernazza in about 1.5 hours. It's one of the more challenging Cinque Terre hikes—steep sections, stairs, and dramatic views.
**Toward Manarola**: The trail south reaches Manarola in about 1 hour. Less dramatic than the Vernazza path but beautiful, with the famous Groppo viewpoint along the way.
**Into the terraces**: Agricultural paths lead upward from the village into the vineyards. These aren't marked tourist routes—walk carefully, stay on paths, and respect working land.
**The sanctuary trail**: A longer path climbs to the Santuario di San Bernardino, offering panoramic views and spiritual destination.

items.name: Station to Village
items.intro: The 382-step climb that begins every Corniglia visit—and how to approach it.
items.description: From the train station, the Lardarina begins immediately. The stairs climb in long switchbacks, each turn revealing more of the coast. There's no shortcut, no alternative walking route—just the stairs or the shuttle bus. Take breaks at the switchbacks. Don't try to rush. The village will wait.
items.giuliaComment: I've climbed the Lardarina thousands of times. The secret is rhythm—find a pace you can maintain, don't stop unless you need to, let your legs find their own tempo. Fight the stairs and they win. Accept them and they're just stairs.
items.signature: Where the journey is the entrance fee

items.name: To Guvano Beach
items.intro: The beach below Corniglia—dramatic to look at, challenging to reach.
items.description: Guvano Beach sits directly below Corniglia's cliffs. Access was once via an old railway tunnel (now closed) or via a steep, difficult path. Currently, the easiest access is by water—kayak or boat. The beach itself is rocky and wild, the kind of secret spot that requires effort.
items.giuliaComment: Guvano was our hidden beach before tourism. Now it's famous but still hard to reach. If you're determined to swim from Corniglia, this is the option—but consider the boat tour alternative. Much easier.

items.name: The Village Loop
items.intro: The ten-minute walk that covers everything—useful for orientation, unnecessary for navigation.
items.description: Walk Via Fieschi from the church to the terrazza. Turn into any alley that interests you. Loop back via the other side of the village. You've now seen everything Corniglia offers within its bounds. The exploration beyond—into terraces, toward other villages—is where the real discovery begins.
items.giuliaComment: First-time visitors sometimes ask what they're missing. In Corniglia, nothing is hidden. The village is small and open. The exploration is about depth, not breadth—sitting longer, looking more carefully, watching how light changes.

interludes.title: The Getting Lost Impossibility
interludes.quote: You cannot get lost in Corniglia. The village is too small. Walk any direction and within minutes you reach either the main street or a cliff edge. The disorientation some visitors feel isn't geographic—it's temporal. Without the rush of other villages, time moves differently here.

body.title: The Simplest Navigation
content: Corniglia's navigation story is simple: climb the stairs, walk the main street, explore the terraces, admire the views. There is no maze to master, no hidden shortcuts to discover, no geographic complexity to decode.
What Corniglia offers instead is clarity—a village small enough to understand immediately, leaving your attention free for what matters: the terraces, the wine, the quiet, the views.
The only navigation challenge is getting here. Once you've climbed the Lardarina, everything else is easy. Let the simplicity of the layout become permission to slow down.
